awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Integrative mechanisms underlying the regulation of intestinal form and function
awd_abstract_narration:
The small intestine is the principal gateway for the uptake of nutrients from meals, the largest of the body's endocrine and immune organs, and hosts an immense bacterial community that is thought to influence all realms of the body's physiology. The intestine also can remodel its structure and function to match meal size, to accommodate changes in diet, and to compensate for loss due to disease or surgery, but little is currently known about the precise mechanisms that underlie this remodeling. The ultimate goal of this collaborative research is to identify the signaling and structural mechanisms that enable the vertebrate intestine to modulate structure and function. Rather than relying on traditional laboratory research animals to achieve this goal, this program takes advantage of the extreme ability of some snakes (pythons, boas, and rattlesnakes) to remodel their small intestine with each meal. By comparing the cellular and molecular responses of the small intestine to feeding and fasting among snakes that feed regularly versus sporadically, and between snakes and other vertebrates, coupled with available genomic resources, this research program will provide new insight into the mechanisms that underlie intestinal remodeling in vertebrates. An exciting novelty of this research is the incorporation of non-traditional model species (i.e., snakes) that have the potential to reveal previously unknown or overlooked mechanisms and that may be important for driving new discoveries for the therapeutic treatment of intestinal diseases. The project's outreach components include workshops on the generation and analyses of gene expression data, and public lectures and animal-based exhibitions to local schools, camps, and museums.

Vertebrates possess the physiological capacities to alter intestinal performance that are adaptively linked to their feeding habits. For example, species that naturally experience long episodes of fasting between large meals (e.g., sit-and-wait foraging snakes) experience rapid upregulation of intestinal form and function with feeding, and subsequent intestinal atrophy and downregulation following digestion. In contrast, frequently feeding species (e.g., active-foraging snakes) experience only modest change in intestinal form and function with each meal. Currently unknown are the cellular and molecular mechanisms that underlie the structural and functional flexibility of the intestine, and whether such mechanisms are shared across vertebrates that widely or narrowly regulate intestinal performance. By leveraging the extreme range in intestinal responses exhibited by snakes and other vertebrates, and recently available genomic resources, this research program will identify the underlying mechanisms of intestinal flexibility and. test whether these mechanisms are shared across lineages and regulatory phenotypes. This goal will be accomplished by pursuing three aims: (1) identify the cellular and structural mechanisms that underlie the modulation of intestinal form, and whether form dictates the regulation of intestinal function; (2) link transcriptional and post-translational mechanisms to phenotypic changes in intestinal structure and function; and (3) test whether shared or unique sets of molecular mechanisms drive similar phenotypic responses among vertebrates. Ultimately, this research will identify the signaling and structural mechanisms by which vertebrates modulate intestinal form and function.

por.por_cntn:
Through our research publications and presentations, we provided a broadly integrative analysis and explanation of the proximate and evolutionary mechanisms responsible for an extreme phenotypic response. This approach will help establish a template for future integrative studies in organismal evolutionary design and physiology. Additionally, this work continues to demonstrate the importance of studying non-traditional animal model systems, such as the snakes that we utilized, for understanding key biological processes.  It also provides strong arguments for leveraging the extreme phenotypic responses of such models to decipher the underlying mechanisms of many medically relevant phenomena, such as tissue regeneration. 

The major goals of this grant were:

  • To examine the interplay between intestinal remodeling and the regulation of intestinal function.
  • To identify the cellular and molecular mechanisms that underlie the modulation of intestinal form and function with feeding.
  • To construct signaling and regulator pathways responsible for intestinal remodeling.
  • To determine whether shared or unique suites of molecular mechanisms drive similar phenotypic responses among vertebrates.

Key outcomes or achievements:

We have demonstrated that boa constrictors experience wide regulation of intestinal performance with feeding, whereas the water snakes and the Amazon tree boas experience more modest changes (< 65%) in intestinal nutrient uptake rates with feeding. Amazon tree boas did demonstrate an elevated increase in intestinal hydrolase activity relative to water snakes, though that may be due largely to their significant increase (by 180%) in small intestinal mass. Additionally, we published the genome of the Prairie Rattlesnake (Schield et al., 2019), which represented the first full chromosome-level genome available for any reptile, at the time of its publication. We also provided the first annotation of the already sequenced but unannotated Boa constrictor genome (Card et al., 2019), based in part on RNAseq data collected from these studies. All genomic and proteomic data was made publicly available through appropriate online databases (e.g., NCBI) as it become available and was vetted.

We were able to fully integrate multiple scales of data from tissue-level measurements to changes in gene expression and post-translational modifications to identify core mechanisms driving the extreme regenerative response. We presented a new model hypothesis of a switch-like role between stress response and growth signaling pathways to balance the need to mitigate metabolic stress with regenerating new tissue to support intestinal absorption.

The project provided training for 1 post-doctoral researcher, 2 graduate students and 22 undergraduate students. Undergraduate and graduate students were involved in the care of the animals and in experiments to sample and weigh organs, process tissues for histology, conduct measurements of intestinal nutrient transport, and perform assays to quantify intestinal enzyme activities, analyze organ masses, and utilize microscopy for morphometric analyses of intestinal tissues. Professional development for the post-doctoral researcher and graduate students also included advanced training for sample preparation and use of the electron microscope, student supervisory roles, organizing and scheduling of laboratory projects, and manuscript development.

Impact of society and beyond Science and Technology:

Undergraduate students had opportunities to conduct research that supported their classroom learning and exposed them to techniques and technologies not available in most standard teaching laboratories. Students learned how to properly document and record data then input, analyze and present data. These are extremely valuable skills for students to develop in preparation for the next steps in their career path.

The training and hands-on interactions the undergraduate and graduate students received allowed them to talk to the public, during our outreach programs, about the animals and their use in research. People are naturally fascinated by the animals and become intrigued from our explanations of how we use them to study how organs and tissues such as intestine, liver, kidney, and pancreas respond to cues such as food availability and how our work can be linked to human biology and health.
